title: substr existing table metadata in zooKeeper differs in partition key expression

labels.name: potential bug
labels.description: To be reviewed by developers and confirmed/rejected.

body:
**Describe what's wrong**
When version 20.12 is upgraded to version 21.3, an old table is created in a new replica. The local metadata is inconsistent with the zk metadata

**Does it reproduce on recent release?**

21.3 version later

**Enable crash reporting**

Code: 342. DB::Exception: Received from localhost:9000. DB::Exception: Existing table metadata in ZooKeeper differs in partition key expression. Stored in ZooKeeper: toYYYYMMDD(toDateTime(substr(create_tm, 1, 19))), local: toYYYYMMDD(toDateTime(substring(create_tm, 1, 19))). 


**How to reproduce**
(1) 20.12  version create a table
```
 CREATE TABLE gdm_m07_cps_batch_limit_cate_da_local
(
    `consume_lim` Nullable(String),
    `item_second_cate_cd` Nullable(String),
    `item_third_cate_cd` Nullable(String),
    `present_id` Nullable(String),
    `limit_rule_type_cd` Nullable(String),
    `cate_valid_flag` Nullable(String),
    `batch_id` String,
    `item_third_cate_name` Nullable(String),
    `item_first_cate_name` Nullable(String),
    `cps_face_value` Nullable(String),
    `item_second_cate_name` Nullable(String),
    `activity_key` Nullable(String),
    `activity_applicant_erp_acct` Nullable(String),
    `create_tm` String,
    `cate_use_rule_cd` Nullable(String),
    `item_first_cate_cd` Nullable(String),
    `cps_cate_cd` Nullable(String),
    `cps_name` Nullable(String)
)
ENGINE = ReplicatedReplacingMergeTree('/clickhouse/LOCAL_CK_TS_01/jdob_ha/default/{shard}/gdm_m07_cps_batch_limit_cate_da', '{replica}')
PARTITION BY toYYYYMMDD(toDateTime(substr(create_tm, 1, 19)))
ORDER BY (batch_id, coalesce(item_first_cate_cd, ''), coalesce(item_second_cate_cd, ''), coalesce(item_third_cate_cd, ''))
TTL toDateTime(substr(create_tm, 1, 19)) + toIntervalDay(30)
SETTINGS index_granularity = 8192
```
(2) upgrade version 21.3，add a new replica，create the table above
```
Code: 342. DB::Exception: Received from localhost:9000. DB::Exception: Existing table metadata in ZooKeeper differs in partition key expression. Stored in ZooKeeper: toYYYYMMDD(toDateTime(substr(create_tm, 1, 19))), local: toYYYYMMDD(toDateTime(substring(create_tm, 1, 19))). 
```

title: Refreshable Materialized Views
body:
**Use Case**

Automate periodic imports of data into ClickHouse. Automate batch jobs for data transformation.


**Requirements**

It should run a query with some schedule and atomically replace a table with the result.

Schedule can be aligned to calendar like "3 AM every Thursday" or not aligned like "30 seconds after previous import has been finished".

It can contain some concurrency limits like "don't do more than 5 jobs of this type concurrently". Limits should work within named "concurrency group". The job also can have numeric priority to control what to run first when resources are available.

If it was not possible to run the job due to concurrency limits or if server was not up, the setting should control if it needs to run as soon as possible or skip to the next update time if more than some ratio of time before next update already passed.

The settings for randomization to avoid DoS of the sources like "spread the next update time around three minutes".

Error recovery: do up to N retries with some initial timeout and exponential backoff saturated up to another timeout.

Chaining and dependencies between the jobs: run a job only after other specified jobs are finished.

System table for introspection of these jobs and system commands to temporary stop scheduling, or stop or pause already running job, or run the job out of order.

It should be possible to run clickhouse-server with all the jobs disabled before manual command.


**Out of scope**

Incremental data import into partitions by time. Batch jobs with multiple queries.
We can think how to extend this mechanism to something like "every day do import and replace partitions for three previous days".

Coordination of jobs in a cluster. (Should be easily extended with schedule in Keeper).

Backing up old tables after refresh (e.g. store N backups in renamed tables), can be easily implemented.


**Proposed solution**

```
CREATE MATERIALIZED VIEW name

REFRESH 

    EVERY 1 WEEK /* on Mondays */
    | EVERY 1 WEEK OFFSET 2 DAY 3 HOUR /* Wednedsday 3 AM */
    | EVERY 30 SECOND /* on 00 and 30 second every minute */
    | AFTER 30 SECOND /* unaligned, 30 seconds after previous update has been finished */
    
    RANDOMIZE FOR 3 MINUTE /* spread uniformly random plus minus 1.5 minutes */
    
DEPENDS ON other_view1, other_view2...  /* run after subsequent finish of these views, only for AFTER */
    
SETTINGS /* fine settings for a refresh process */
    max_concurrency = 3,
    concurrency_group = 'import_from_mysql',
    priority = 1,
    max_retries = 5,
    backoff_min_timeout = 10,
    backoff_max_timeout = 600,
    backoff_exponent = 2,
    skip_update_after_seconds = 1000,
    skip_update_after_ratio = 0.5

ENGINE = /* how to store data */

AS SELECT /* what query to run, possibly including the SETTINGS for the query */
```

```
SELECT * FROM system.view_refreshes;
SYSTEM REFRESH VIEW name;    /* ask for refresh out of schedule */
SYSTEM STOP|START VIEW name; /* do not run this view on schedule */
SYSTEM CANCEL|PAUSE|START VIEW name; /* for currently running job */
```

ALTER, DROP, RENAME, DETACH, ATTACH work trivially for these views.
ALTER is similar to CREATE and simply changes everything (the underlying table itself will be replaced on next update).

The underlying table has the same name as the view (the view and its data are represented with the same name in the database).

**Additional context**

With the help of Atomic databases, table replace is lock-free.

Refreshable materialized views will simplify managing some dictionaries. For example, we can create a view to import data from MySQL to EmbeddedRocksDB table and then create a `direct` dictionary on top of this table.

Note: this task is not hard to implement, but it contains many minor details and gotchas.

title: Support multiple columns as primary key in StorageEmbeddedRocksDB

labels.name: pr-improvement
labels.description: Pull request with some product improvements

body:
Changelog category (leave one):
- Improvement


Changelog entry (a user-readable short description of the changes that goes to CHANGELOG.md):
Support multiple columns as primary key in StorageEmbeddedRocksDB. closes [#32819](https://github.com/ClickHouse/ClickHouse/issues/32819)

Detailed description / Documentation draft:
For `write`, the primary key columns are serialized in order to be the key in RocksDB.
For `read`, if `WHERE` clause specifies all the primary key columns with `AND`, `EmbeddedRocksDBSource` will `get` from RocksDB by the specified keys. Otherwise, it will iterate through the whole database.

Key tuples specified by a `WHERE` clause are represented by `KeyFieldVectors`, which is in fact a vector of `FieldVectorPtr`, with each `FieldVector` representing the possible value of a primary key column. For example, 
`WHERE key_a IN (1, 2, 3) AND key_b IN (SELECT number FROM numbers(5)`
is represented as `[[1, 2, 3], [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]]`. `EmbeddedRocksDBSource` iterates through `KeyFieldVectors` to generate primary key tuples on the fly in `generate()`. This deduces memory consumption when key tuple number is large.
Each `KeyFieldVectors` can only represents part of key tuples when there is `OR` in `WHERE` clause. `KeyTupleSets`, which is vector of `KeyFieldVectors`, is used to represents all the conditions if there is `OR`. For example,
`WHERE (key_a = 1 AND key_b = 2) OR (key_a = 3 AND key_b = 3)`
is represented by `KeyTupleSets` which is [ [[1], [2]], [[3], [3]] ].
`KeyFieldVectors`s in `KeyTupleSets` are de-duplicated before passing to `EmbeddedRocksDBSource`, this prevent duplicated tuple between clauses. For example, in
`WHERE (key_a IN (1,2) AND key_b IN (3,4,5) AND key_c IN (5,6)) OR (key_a IN (2,3) AND key_b IN (2,3,4) AND key_c IN (6,7))`
both clauses contain [2, 3, 6] and [2, 4, 6], the de-duplication process will split one of the `KeyFieldVectors` to exclude duplicated tuples.

Discussion:
As we don't know if the key tuple exists in database until actually `get` from RocksDB, it's dangerous to blindly iterate all the possible key tuples if the key space is large, e.g., `WHERE key_a IN (SELECT number FROM numbers(100000)) AND key_b IN (SELECT number FROM numbers(100000))`. What I do here is comparing the number of key tuple with the row number of database before `get`, if it's larger that the row number of database, fall back to `all_scan`. I wonder if there is better solution on this.

title: Understanding Explain Plan
body:
What is the difference between the following:

**Expression (( + (Projection + Before ORDER BY)))**  
**Expression ((Projection + Before ORDER BY))**

For one of my queries I replaced the literal 0 with an alias to this literal, that is:
**select 0 from (select 0 as x)** instead of **select x from (select 0 as x);** and it slowed the query by a factor of two! (4 sec instead of 2)
I checked the query plan and the only thing changed is that **Expression (( + (Projection + Before ORDER BY)))**  became **Expression ((Projection + Before ORDER BY))**. 

I though exactly the obvious would happen, that using a literal would be faster than using an alias to that literal.
Any thoughts?

title: UUIDs in Native and *Binary formats

labels.name: comp-documentation
labels.description: Used to run automatic builds of the documentation

body:
We have found a lack that the format of UUIDs is not defined in documentation for Native and *Binary formats.
By default it is expected that it uses normal network byte order but in fact a client has to spilt UUID in network byte order into two Uint64 words and then reverse byte order of each part.
I am not specifically writing "little endian" because the described operation works in both directions.

title: [Cloud Native Feature] make one node run multi-shards
body:
**Use case**
> A clear and concise description of what is the intended usage scenario is.

After separation of storage and compute, It will be very convenient to scale out and add nodes into cluster without data move.
But there is still an issue that dataset should be split and re-shard because size of data shards is less than compute node size.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
> A clear and concise description of what you want to happen.

If we can make one node run multi-shards, there is no need to split dataset in most cases. For example, If one node runs four shards, we can scale out four times nodes without dataset spliting.


**Describe alternatives you've considered**
> A clear and concise description of any alternative solutions or features you've considered.

A cluster shard is made of (or identified by) host_address, port and default_database. We can use multi `ReplicatedDatabases` with different database name as default_database in a compute node. So we can setup a special cluster which contains compute nodes run multi-shards.

**Additional context**
> Add any other context or screenshots about the feature request here.

We can create a new entity whose kind is `CLUSTER`
```CREATE CLUSTER cluster_name SETTINGS('/clickhouse/zookeeper-path', 'share storage config', shard_size=16)```

After above statement, a ZK-node will be created, whose children contain `ReplicatedDatabase` metadata node and cluster discovery node, etc.
We can use this PR [#31442](https://github.com/ClickHouse/ClickHouse/pull/31442) idea to generate a dynamic `special cluster` map config

Supposing we have four compute nodes, and make a normal cluster `default`

```CREATE DATABASE cloud_db ON CLUSTER default ENGINE = Cloud('/clickhouse/zookeeper-path')```

Here we import a new database engine `Cloud`, it will register node itself into Cluster through zookeeper-path and join leader election.
Only one leader can play the role of shard assignment and rebalance when failover.

After shard assignment, every compute node receives multi-shards such as shard4/shard5/shard6/shard7, then the `Cloud` database engine will create four internal databases which engine is `ReplicatedDatabase` and named shard4, shard5, shard6, shard7. All tables created in these databases will use the share storage config and storage_policies from zookeeper.

Users work in cloud_db, create MergeTree family tables adding sharding_key as settings, the `Cloud` database will create `Distributed` table additionally in `ReplicatedDatabase`, for example Distributed(cluster, '', table, sharding_key), make database empty and use default_database in cluster for each shard.  And only load or show `Distributed` tables from metadata in zookeeper path.
Local table and distributed table always make user confused. Cloud database only show logical table that may be more user-friendly.

After all compute nodes register and finish shard assignment, all shards are ready and the `special cluster` can work.
If the speed of failover is fast enough, the Replicated*MergeTree is not recommended, because share storage make data service high available.

A high performance and transactional data part service will better in `Cloud Native Warehouse`

title: Exception when comparing Array(Int64) and Array(UInt64)
body:
**Describe what's wrong**

Comparing Array(Int64) with Array(UInt64) or Array(Int256) with Array(UInt256) throws an `ILLEGAL_TYPE_OF_ARGUMENT` exception. Comparing arrays of other integer sizes works.

**Does it reproduce on recent release?**

* 21.9.4.35
* 21.8.9.13

**How to reproduce**

* 21.8.9.13
* clickhouse client
* Run queries `SELECT [toInt64(1)] == [toUInt64(1)]` or `SELECT [toInt256(1)] == [toUInt256(1)]`

**Expected behavior**

`SELECT [toInt64(1)] == [toUInt64(1)]` should return 1. It does for all other integer sizes
```
SELECT
    [toInt8(1)] = [toUInt8(1)] AS `8`,
    [toInt16(1)] = [toUInt16(1)] AS `16`,
    [toInt32(1)] = [toUInt32(1)] AS `32`,
    [toInt128(1)] = [toUInt128(1)] AS `128`

Query id: e2f218b5-dfea-475c-92c6-85e041945bda

┌─8─┬─16─┬─32─┬─128─┐
│ 1 │  1 │  1 │   1 │
└───┴────┴────┴─────┘

1 rows in set. Elapsed: 0.007 sec.
```

**Error message and/or stacktrace**

```
SELECT [toInt64(1)] = [toUInt64(1)] AS `64`

Query id: d4aae777-aca5-4d3d-83eb-8703a3ed2d43


0 rows in set. Elapsed: 0.018 sec.

Received exception from server (version 21.8.9):
Code: 43. DB::Exception: Received from localhost:9000. DB::Exception: Illegal types of arguments (Array(Int64), Array(UInt64)) of function equals: While processing [toInt64(1)] = [toUInt64(1)] AS `64`.
```

title: Respect cgroup-v2 limits on CPU and memory
body:
**Use case**

> A clear and concise description of what is the intended usage scenario is.

After #30574, #33342, `getMemoryAmount` and `getNumberOfPhysicalCPUCores` respect [cgroup v1](https://www.kernel.org/doc/html/latest/admin-guide/cgroup-v1/index.html) llimits and can get the right amount of CPU and memory when running inside a docker container.

Linux 4.5 introduce [control group v2](https://www.kernel.org/doc/html/latest/admin-guide/cgroup-v2.html) restriction. Those functions don't follow the restriction of cgroup v2. However, AFAIK, cgroup v2 is not enabled by default and is not widely used, so I create an issue for it. One can pick up this issue if he/she is interested in it.

/cc @bobrik from https://github.com/ClickHouse/ClickHouse/pull/33342#issuecomment-1005349821

**Describe the solution you'd like**

> A clear and concise description of what you want to happen.

Follow the CPU/Memory restriction on cgroup v2

**Describe alternatives you've considered**

> A clear and concise description of any alternative solutions or features you've considered.

**Additional context**

> Add any other context or screenshots about the feature request here.

Reference:
* Control Group v2: https://www.kernel.org/doc/html/latest/admin-guide/cgroup-v2.html

title: Metric HTTPConnection may be incorrect
body:
HTTPConnection is counted on the HTTPHandler level.  While the http connections are maintained on Poco level. 

That means for example that we can open 1000 connections to HTTP but until some HTTP requests will be sent and poco will call the HTTP hander the metric will be showing 0. 

So actually it counts in-flight http queries, not connections. 

Ideally would be to count both real connections & in-flight http queries.

Also may be a counter of served http queries could be nice (to catch / count fast queries which are hard to see via system.metrics)

Loosely related to https://github.com/ClickHouse/ClickHouse/issues/23858

title: Invalid Kerberos auth flow: Server sends 403 instead of 401
body:
(you don't have to strictly follow this form)

**Describe the unexpected behaviour**
Server behavior during Kerberos authentication does not conform to [RFC4559](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc4559#section-4.1). When a client authenticates using Kerberos, it *may* not send authentication headers on first request. In that case, the server should send a "401 Unauthorized" status code, and a "WWW-Authenticate:" header, which triggers SPNEGO workflow in Curl. However, ClickHouse does not do that and sends back a HTTP 403 instead

**How to reproduce**
* Observed on 21.9 but likely is present in latest version
* HTTP interface
* Kerberos authentication

```
curl -v -u : --negotiate "http://clickhouse.server:8123/?query=SELECT+VERSION()"
```

**Sent headers**
```
> GET ?query=SELECT+VERSION()
> User-Agent: curl/7.29.0
> Host: clickhouse.server:8123
> Accept */*
```
**Expected server response**
```
< HTTP/1.1 401 Unauthorized
< Date: .....
< Connection: Keep-Alive
< WWW-Authenticate: Negotiate
< Content-Type: .....
```

**Observed server response**
```
< HTTP/1.1 403 Forbidden
< Date: .....
< Connection: Keep-Alive
< X-Clickhouse-Exception-Code: 516
< Content-Type: .....

Code: 516. DB::Exception: default: Authentication failed: password is incorrect or there is no user with such name. (AUTHENTICATION_FAILED) (version 21.9.2.1)
```

title: Incorrect scalar subquery result

labels.name: potential bug
labels.description: To be reviewed by developers and confirmed/rejected.

body:
**Describe what's wrong**

For some reason, the first column of a select is not returning the scalar result and instead returns something else: 


```
CREATE TABLE t1 (i Int64, j Int64) ENGINE = Memory;
INSERT INTO t1 SELECT number, number FROM system.numbers LIMIT 10;
SELECT
        (SELECT max(i) FROM t1) as i,
        (SELECT max(i) FROM t1) as j,
        (SELECT max(i) FROM t1) as k,
        (SELECT max(i) FROM t1) as l
FROM t1
```

* Result:
```
┌─i─┬─j─┬─k─┬─l─┐
│ 0 │ 9 │ 9 │ 9 │
│ 1 │ 9 │ 9 │ 9 │
│ 2 │ 9 │ 9 │ 9 │
│ 3 │ 9 │ 9 │ 9 │
│ 4 │ 9 │ 9 │ 9 │
│ 5 │ 9 │ 9 │ 9 │
│ 6 │ 9 │ 9 │ 9 │
│ 7 │ 9 │ 9 │ 9 │
│ 8 │ 9 │ 9 │ 9 │
│ 9 │ 9 │ 9 │ 9 │
└───┴───┴───┴───┘
```

* Expected:
```
┌─i─┬─j─┬─k─┬─l─┐
│ 9 │ 9 │ 9 │ 9 │
│ 9 │ 9 │ 9 │ 9 │
│ 9 │ 9 │ 9 │ 9 │
│ 9 │ 9 │ 9 │ 9 │
│ 9 │ 9 │ 9 │ 9 │
│ 9 │ 9 │ 9 │ 9 │
│ 9 │ 9 │ 9 │ 9 │
│ 9 │ 9 │ 9 │ 9 │
│ 9 │ 9 │ 9 │ 9 │
│ 9 │ 9 │ 9 │ 9 │
└───┴───┴───┴───┘


```


This also happens if I use a CTE to declare **once** the subquery:
```
WITH (
        SELECT max(i)
        FROM t1
    ) AS value
SELECT
    value AS i,
    value AS j,
    value AS k,
    value AS l
FROM t1

Query id: 8a85ed02-0ad7-4fe4-b01f-eabbb7521d52

```


**Does it reproduce on recent release?**

Tested on 20.7 (the oldest I keep around) and master and both exhibit the same behaviour so I guess everything is affected.


On master, describing the table shows that the first column didn't receive the scalar replacement, otherwise it would have been Nullable(Int64):

```

title: Client fault tolerant connection

labels.name: pr-feature
labels.description: Pull request with new product feature

labels.name: doc-alert
labels.description: PR where any documentation work is needed or proceeded

body:
Changelog category (leave one):

- New Feature

Changelog entry (a user-readable short description of the changes that goes to CHANGELOG.md):
Parameter `--host` can accept multiple hosts. In case of unavailability of one of them, the client will try to connect to the next one.

Detailed description / Documentation draft:
Feature accept setting multiple hosts for connection. It approves fault tolerance of connection because when one host isn't alive client can try to connect to another one.

Parameter `--host` can accept multiple addresses. Every address must contain resolvable host and can also contain portif it isn't set, port from `--port` is used). Example of usage:
`clickhouse-client --host host1:1 host2 host3:3 --port 2 --query "SELECT 1"`

When multiple addresses are passed to the host argument and the first one is unavailable, the client will try to connect to the next one (round robin approach). In the example, if client can't connect to `host1:1`, it will try to connect to `host2` and port `2`, which is set in `--port`.


> Information about CI checks: https://clickhouse.tech/docs/en/development/continuous-integration/

title: File/S3/HDFS as Database engine
body:
**Use case**

Process a bunch of files in the most intuitive way.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

After #32455 is implemented, the format and structure of remote datasets is autodetected.
So, we can write `SELECT * FROM url('https://datasets.clickhouse.com/github_events_v2.native.xz')` without specifying data format or data structure.

Now let's look at the directory with files as a database.
It will allow to write something like:

```
SELECT * FROM "data.parquet"
```

The database engine should do lazy listing of the files.
The table structure should also be obtained lazily to avoid slow SHOW TABLES.

Database engine can take the following parameters:
- prefix for files;
- filter for filenames / file paths, optional (a question - should it be regexp or glob style);
- should it do recursive directory traversal or look at the immediate directory only (the latter by default);
- maybe a rule to glue some files together by pattern to represent them as a single table;
- maybe a regexp to transform names;
- default format if it is not autodetected, optional (skip unknown by default);

**Caveats**

`SELECT * FROM system.tables` without filters will become slower if these types of databases exist.

**Additional ideas**

We can introduce the notion of overlay databases (one database that can shadow tables from another database) and add File database to `clickhouse-local` to be available under default database.

title: Maintain list of trusted servers for access control
body:
Sorry if this has been discussed before but I didn't find a similar topic on github :p

As of now, if a user has the privilege to use `jdbc` table function, she/he can access all declared external datasources, read or write. It's fine for a development/testing environment but definitely not for production. Does it make sense to enhance ClickHouse to maintain list of trusted servers or names(alias of a server or an endpoint) to tighten control of accessing external datasources via table functions like `url`, `remote`, `mysql`, and `jdbc` etc.? Whitelist and blacklist can be used to simplify configuration. For example:

1. create a server
  ```sql
  CREATE SERVER bridge1 HOST IP '127.0.0.1' COMMENT 'local testing';
  ```
2. grant user access
  ```sql
  GRANT ALL ON SERVER bridge1 TO john;
  ```
3. access remote server
  ```sql
  -- extract server from the URL
  -- and then check against ACL to see if john is allowed to access the server
  select * from url('https://127.0.0.1/some/path?param=value', CSV, 'value String')
  ```

title: Pass execution context to table functions for accessing external datasource
body:
Does it make sense to pass execution context to table functions for accessing external datasource?

Taking `url` and `jdbc` as example, since they're based on http protocol, it would be great if ClickHouse can put below headers in **request**. With that, extension like JDBC bridge can implement role-based access control and detect recursive query like mentioned in #33802. 

| Header | Mandatory | Description |
| ------- | ----------- | ----------- |
| User-Agent | N | server/lib + version |
| X-ClickHouse-Server-Display-Name | N | server display name |
| X-ClickHouse-Format | N | different default value for different table function |
| X-ClickHouse-Query-Id | Y | query id |
| X-ClickHouse-User | Y | user who issued the query on ClickHouse, it could be user name, id or even a hash for security reason |
| X-ClickHouse-Timezone | Y | server time zone |
| X-ClickHouse-Version | N |server version |
| X-ClickHouse-Revision | N | server revision |

Note: more headers can be added for tracing when needed.

SELECT count(value) AS a
FROM test
SETTINGS optimize_functions_to_subcolumns = 1

┌─sum(not(value.null))─┐
│                    0 │
└──────────────────────┘

1 rows in set. Elapsed: 0.032 sec. Processed 32.50 million rows, 32.50 MB (1.00 billion rows/s., 1.00 GB/s.)
```

**Expected behavior**

ClickHouse should use alias name.

title: MATERIALIZE COLUMN FINAL

labels.name: comp-documentation
labels.description: Used to run automatic builds of the documentation

body:
https://clickhouse.com/docs/en/sql-reference/statements/alter/column/#materialize-column
MATERIALIZE COLUMN FINAL  was never implemented  https://github.com/ClickHouse/ClickHouse/pull/28011

MATERIALIZE COLUMN behave differently from the documentation states.

MATERIALIZE COLUMN updates values always (behaves as FINAL should behave).

title: ROW POLICY triggering access issue
body:
**Describe the issue**

We should clarify the behavior of

`CREATE ROW POLICY [policy_name] ON [db.table] FOR SELECT`

If any ROW POLICY is created on a table, all access to that table for other users and roles must be explicitly granted to that table by another matching ROW POLICY.  So in the case of the access rights on the node you are testing on, to continue to allow admin and other users to query system.tables, you would need an additional row policy such as

`CREATE ROW POLICY default_row_policy ON system.tables FOR SELECT USING 1 TO ALL EXCEPT test_user_3, analytics_user`

This behavior is by design but it is confusing to assign a restriction to one user or role and have it affect other users.

**How to reproduce**

```
CREATE DATABASE test;

CREATE TABLE test.test_db_3
(
    'Title' String,
    'id' UInt32
)
ENGINE = MergeTree()
ORDER BY (id)

CREATE ROLE test_role_1 SETTINGS log_profile_events = 1 READONLY, log_queries = 1 READONLY, log_query_settings = 1 READONLY, log_query_threads = 1 READONLY ;

CREATE USER test_user_3 IDENTIFIED WITH plaintext_password by 'password' DEFAULT ROLE test_role_1

CREATE ROW POLICY test_user_3_tables_filter ON system.tables FOR SELECT USING database = 'test_db_3' TO test_user_3 ;
```

* Which ClickHouse server version to use: 2021-12-15

* Non-default settings, if any:
<access_management>1</access_management>

**Expected behavior**
A ROW POLICY should only restrict the permission of the specified user or the documentation should be more clear about how to use it.

title: Segmentation fault on ECS Fargate when reading from S3

labels.name: crash
labels.description: Crash / segfault / abort

labels.name: potential bug
labels.description: To be reviewed by developers and confirmed/rejected.

body:
**Describe what's wrong**

I am trying to execute `select * from s3(…)` and ClickHouse dies with the following output:

```
SELECT *
FROM s3('…', 'TSV', 'root String')

Query id: 86972283-b218-493b-a56b-c1125f083ce6

[85b9a88609d0454f8fb03fa59362654d-2580379071] 2022.01.19 07:46:56.066552 [ 251 ] <Fatal> BaseDaemon: ########################################
[85b9a88609d0454f8fb03fa59362654d-2580379071] 2022.01.19 07:46:56.066602 [ 251 ] <Fatal> BaseDaemon: (version 21.12.3.32 (official build), build id: FA4A7F489F3FF6E3) (from thread 97) (query_id: 86972283-b218-493b-a56b-c1125f083ce6) Received signal Segmentation fault (11)
[85b9a88609d0454f8fb03fa59362654d-2580379071] 2022.01.19 07:46:56.066622 [ 251 ] <Fatal> BaseDaemon: Address: 0x7f2172f7a5c0 Access: read. Attempted access has violated the permissions assigned to the memory area.
[85b9a88609d0454f8fb03fa59362654d-2580379071] 2022.01.19 07:46:56.066636 [ 251 ] <Fatal> BaseDaemon: Stack trace: 0x1257420f 0x7f2207ded3c0
[85b9a88609d0454f8fb03fa59362654d-2580379071] 2022.01.19 07:46:56.066666 [ 251 ] <Fatal> BaseDaemon: 0. ? @ 0x1257420f in /usr/bin/clickhouse
[85b9a88609d0454f8fb03fa59362654d-2580379071] 2022.01.19 07:46:56.066700 [ 251 ] <Fatal> BaseDaemon: 1. ? @ 0x7f2207ded3c0 in ?
[85b9a88609d0454f8fb03fa59362654d-2580379071] 2022.01.19 07:46:56.194581 [ 251 ] <Fatal> BaseDaemon: Calculated checksum of the binary: 5BEBF5792A40F7E345921EDA3698245B. There is no information about the reference checksum.
Exception on client:
Code: 32. DB::Exception: Attempt to read after eof: while receiving packet from 10.0.1.32:9000. (ATTEMPT_TO_READ_AFTER_EOF)

Connecting to 10.0.1.32:9000 as user default.
Code: 210. DB::NetException: Connection refused (10.0.1.32:9000). (NETWORK_ERROR)
```

**Does it reproduce on recent release?**

I use Docker image `yandex/clickhouse-server:21.12.3.32`.

**How to reproduce**

I have defined the following Dockerfile:

```
FROM yandex/clickhouse-server:21.12.3.32
RUN echo '<clickhouse><s3><s3><endpoint>https://s3.eu-central-1.amazonaws.com/my-bucket/some/prefix/</endpoint><use_environment_credentials>true</use_environment_credentials></s3></s3></clickhouse>' \
        > /etc/clickhouse-server/config.d/s3.xml
```

All it does is sets `use_environment_credentials=true` for my bucket in `eu-central-1` AWS region. This is required since I am running ClickHouse on ECS Fargate (in a container) with an IAM role attached to a task.

Here is service definition in Terraform:
```terraform
locals {
  clickhouse-server-http-port   = 8123
  clickhouse-server-native-port = 9000
}

resource "aws_ecs_task_definition" "clickhouse-server" {
  family                   = "clickhouse-server"
  cpu                      = 2048
  memory                   = 8192
  network_mode             = "awsvpc"
  execution_role_arn       = aws_iam_role.ecs-exec.arn
  requires_compatibilities = ["FARGATE"]
  task_role_arn            = aws_iam_role.clickhouse-access-s3.arn  # HERE I ATTACH A ROLE TO USE TO ACCESS S3
  container_definitions    = jsonencode([
    {
      name             = "clickhouse-server"
      image            = # my custom image
      portMappings     = [
        { containerPort = local.clickhouse-server-http-port },
        { containerPort = local.clickhouse-server-native-port },
      ]
      logConfiguration = {
        logDriver = "awslogs"
        options   = {
          awslogs-group         = aws_cloudwatch_log_group.clickhouse-server.name
          awslogs-region        = data.aws_region.current.name
          awslogs-stream-prefix = "clickhouse-server"
        }
      }
    }
  ])
}

resource "aws_iam_role" "clickhouse-access-s3" {
  name               = "clickhouse-access-s3"
  assume_role_policy = data.aws_iam_policy_document.assume-ecs-execution-role.json
  inline_policy {
    name   = "clickhouse-access-s3"
    policy = data.aws_iam_policy_document.clickhouse-access-s3.json
  }
}
data "aws_iam_policy_document" "clickhouse-access-s3" {
  statement {
    effect    = "Allow"
    actions   = ["s3:*"]
    resources = []  # proper S3 permissions here
  }
}

resource "aws_ecs_cluster" "clickhouse-server" {
  name = "clickhouse-server"
}

resource "aws_ecs_service" "clickhouse-server" {
  name            = "clickhouse-server"
  launch_type     = "FARGATE"
  desired_count   = 1
  task_definition = aws_ecs_task_definition.clickhouse-server.arn
  cluster         = aws_ecs_cluster.clickhouse-server.arn
  # proper network_configuration {…}
}

resource "aws_cloudwatch_log_group" "clickhouse-server" {
  name = "clickhouse-server"
}
```

When using s3 table function without config file (running container from pure `yandex/clickhouse-server:21.12.3.32` image without my custom Dockerfile), I was able to read this file from S3 by providing explicit AWS credentials. Now, when configuration is added, the operation fails even with AWS credentials explicitly provided. The error is the same: see traceback above, ClickHouse container dies.

Solution also works when container is run using `docker run` simply on an EC2 instance (without Fargate service). No error also appears if the service is run without task role attached (`task_role_arn=null` above).

**Expected behavior**

I expect s3 table function to use `$AWS_CONTAINER_CREDENTIALS_RELATIVE_URI` when `use_environment_credentials` enabled, and looks like codebase supports it:

https://github.com/ClickHouse/ClickHouse/blob/35883e0dae7be1ffa8948e5c56a168262fc7366f/src/IO/S3Common.cpp#L524-L526

[AWS documentation](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonECS/latest/developerguide/task-iam-roles.html) on AWS_CONTAINER_CREDENTIALS_RELATIVE_URI.

S3 endpoint settings [documentation](https://clickhouse.com/docs/en/engines/table-engines/integrations/s3/#endpoint-settings).

body:
**Use case**

One random guy asked it on the internet.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

On output it will create SQLite database with a single table named `table`.
On input it will read SQLite database and pick the first table from it.

Most likely it has to be read from seekable file.
Most likely it will require to substitute some wrapper around ReadBuffer/WriteBuffer to make SQLite work.
Alternatively it can work by slurping it into memory.

**Additional notes**

Do you know that we alrady have `SQLite` as table and database engines?

title: Lower amount of recursion in Parser
body:
We are using hand-written recursive descent parser and it is alright.

But it is using too deep recursion to parse expression with operators.
Something like 10 stack frames to parse any expression element.

We can get rid of the excessive recursion by using "precendence climbing" method or similar:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operator-precedence_parser

It is like parsing expression greedy from left to right and binding the operators to arguments according to the priorities.

We have the following operators:

```
a[b]
a.b

-a
+a

NOT a

DATE a
TIMESTAMP a

INTERVAL a UNIT

a IS NULL
a IS NOT NULL

a::Type

a + b
a - b
a * b
a / b
a % b
a DIV b
a MOD b
a || b

a < b
a > b
a <= b
a >= b
a = b
a == b
a != b
a <> b

a AND b
a OR b

a ? b : c
a BETWEEN b AND c

[a, b...]
(a, b...)

f(a, b...)

a -> b

a AS b
a b          - only in SELECT expression list

CASE a WHEN b THEN c ... [ELSE d] END
CASE WHEN a THEN b ... [ELSE d] END
```

It is ok if you slightly change some relative priorities of the operators or break some very strange cases.

Example showing too deep recursion:

```
clickhouse-local --max_parser_depth 100000 --query "SELECT f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f(f()))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))) Aborted (core dumped)
```

Less than 1000 levels of nesting are exhausting 2 MiB stack.

title: Allow to pass UUID in MessagePack
body:
It is very efficient to use MessagePack as input data format to pass strict data to ClickHouse and UUID field type to store it. Unfortunately at this moment ClickHouse doesn't handle UUIDs presented in MessagePack and we have to store UUIDs as a fixed strings.
I want to suggest to add parsing UUIDs to MessagePack input parser in two forms:
- as a MessagePack's string of 36 chracters
- as a MessagePack's 16-bytes binary (https://github.com/msgpack/msgpack/blob/master/spec.md#bin-format-family)

title: TRUNCATE TABLE in Replicated DB if multiple partitions exist raises exception: Cannot add ZooKeeper operation because query is executed

labels.name: bug experimental
labels.description: Bug in the feature that should not be used in production

body:
### Version
21.12.3.32

### Details
Create Replicated DB
```
CREATE DATABASE IF NOT EXISTS test ON CLUSTER 'test_shard_localhost'
ENGINE = Replicated('/clickhouse/{cluster}/db/test', '{shard}', '{replica}') ;
```

Create Table in Replicated DB
```
CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS test.events
(
    event_day Date,
    event_id String
)
ENGINE = ReplicatedMergeTree('/clickhouse/{cluster}/tables/{uuid}/{shard}', '{replica}')
PARTITION BY (toYYYYMM(event_day))
ORDER BY (event_day);
```

Try to insert data and do truncate.  
If adding data that fits into one partition => truncate works OK:
```
INSERT INTO test.events(event_day, event_id)
VALUES 
	(toDate('2021-01-01'), 'e1');

TRUNCATE TABLE test.events;
```

If adding data that fits multiple partitions => truncate fails, only first partition removed:
[clickhouse-server.err.log](https://github.com/ClickHouse/ClickHouse/files/7891425/clickhouse-server.err.log)

```
INSERT INTO test.events(event_day, event_id)
VALUES 
	(toDate('2021-01-01'), 'e1'),
	(toDate('2022-01-01'), 'e2');

TRUNCATE TABLE test.events;
 => exception
 DB::Exception: Cannot add ZooKeeper operation because query is executed. It's a bug. (LOGICAL_ERROR)

SELECT * from system.parts 
WHERE database = 'test' and table ='events';  
=> 1 part left still, if trying additional TRUNCATE statements - those would fail also

Function subString Inconsistent behavior between constant and table

**Does it reproduce on recent release?**
all

**How to reproduce**

```sql
create table t (s String) ENGINE=MergeTree() order by s;

title: Parse and store opentelemetry trace-id in big-endian order

labels.name: pr-improvement
labels.description: Pull request with some product improvements

body:
Changelog category (leave one):
- Improvement

Changelog entry (a user-readable short description of the changes that goes to CHANGELOG.md):
- Parse and store OpenTelemetry trace-id in big-endian order


Detailed description / Documentation draft:

ClickHouse now parses the trace id from the opentelemetry HTTP `traceparent` in little end order, which is counterintuitive for users to search the trace in the span log or export the  span log to other system by using URL engine. Users are always struggling dealing with the incorrect string order of the trace id which are stored in ClickHouse and upstream applications.

Let's take an example.

By giving the trace id as **5ff09c5da8c64a1db6c94a073bf0c426**

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6525742/149876858-9054c2a6-0e90-4159-b227-420777f8ea67.png)

However, when we check the records stored in the opentelementry_span_log table, we can see that the trace id is displayed as **6c94a073bf0c426-5ff09c5da8c64a1db**. Note that the first 16 characters and the last 16 characters are in wrong order with the input id.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6525742/149876984-ab880152-55a8-4121-9c19-9148e7d2ebd0.png)

It's not able for us to link the span logs with upstreaming application's together because of the wrong string order.

## Analysis
Current code uses `readHex` function to parse the trace id. It does parse the string from head of the string to tail as if it treats the input in big-endian order.

But the problem is, it uses a multiply operator `x *= 16` to calculate the value.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6525742/149878107-a8d89adb-44f1-4471-8780-ecd2b2756657.png)

For the trace id, its underlying data type is `UInt128`, which is actually an array of two `UInt64`. This `UInt128` overrides the `operator *` that it puts the higher 64 bit at index 1 of the array, the lower 64 bit at index 0 of the array.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6525742/149878058-ca0bc4ae-5fba-436d-bda1-0ba48ad1975b.png)

This is why we see the query result of trace id' string order is reversed.

## The implementation of UUIDStringToNum
Actually, the current function `UUIDStringToNum` treats the input string as big-endian order. That means, the index 0 at the underlying UInt64 array stores the higher 64 bit, while the index 1 stores the lower 64 bits. 

This is a correct behavior that it uses totally different string parse logic that differs from the `readHex` function above.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6525742/149879901-2bdc248d-d266-4c96-88de-d489d3c8a4e8.png)


## Changes
So, in this PR, I changed the parse logic of trace id, to treat it as big-endian order and stores it as big-endian order, like `UUIDStringToNum` has done.

And original `readHex` is replaced by some `unhex` functions to eliminate code duplication. 
Note that `unhexUInt<128>` is not used to parse trace id because it also stores the higher 64-bits at index 1 of underlying UInt64 array.

After this change, the trace_id that are stored in the span log is in the right string order with input, so that we can easily link the records together by this trace_id.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6525742/149879370-b2c74885-e191-40b7-855d-ed2257d3330b.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6525742/149879467-4908de4c-39f9-4916-a556-f0884e525e95.png)

title: After 439 exception clickhouse does not release threads

labels.name: potential bug
labels.description: To be reviewed by developers and confirmed/rejected.

body:
I have a table **A** which have ~ 200M rows and table **B** with same structure. Clickhouse uses in normal state up to 1k threads. I tried transfer data from A to B with query `INSERT INTO B SELECT * FROM A`. Thread count used by clickhouse incremented to 2k and query throws exception  `Code: 439. DB::Exception: Received from localhost:9000. DB::Exception: Cannot schedule a task: no free thread`. After that clickhouse should decrement thread count using for query execution. But thread count still is 2k 

**Does it reproduce on recent release?**

No , i am use clickhouse `21.12.3.32` version


**How to reproduce**

* Which ClickHouse server version to use
*  `21.12.3.32` version
* Queries to run that lead to unexpected result
`INSERT INTO B SELECT * FROM A`

**Expected behavior**

> 1k thread using by clickhouse process

title: Garbage on FS after replicated merge tree table creation with invalid zk path

labels.name: minor
labels.description: Priority: minor

body:
Garbage on a filesystem after error with invalid zk path, you can't create a table with fixed path due to `Directory for table data data/test_db/test_table/ already exists.` error.

> A clear and concise description of what works not as it is supposed to.

I reproduced on 21.8.13.6 and 21.11.9.1

[The list of releases](https://github.com/ClickHouse/ClickHouse/blob/master/utils/list-versions/version_date.tsv)

**How to reproduce**

1. Create Ordinary database(issue less significant on Atomic engine, because it generates new uid on retry)
2. Create ReplicatedMergeTree table with invalid zk path(i.e. without leading /
`CREATE TABLE test_db.test_table (id String) ENGINE = ReplicatedMergeTree('default.test_table', '{replica}') ORDER BY id SETTINGS index_granularity = 8192`, get error `DB::Exception: ZooKeeper path must starts with '/', got 'default.test_table'`
4. Retry query(possibly with fixed zk path), get error `DB::Exception: Directory for table data data/test_db/test_table/ already exists.`

**Expected behavior**
The failed table should not create garbage on fs.

* ClickHouse version: **21.11.5.33**

* Queries to run that lead to slow performance: 

When trying to load data into ClickHouse using clickhouse-copier. The process goes unexpectedly slow. In particular we see slow ALTER TABLE ATTACH PARTITION queries in the query_log.

The query ALTER ATTACH PARTITION copies data from one table to another. There is no network interaction, so the data is copied only within the local disk. This is probably an IO bound task and the speed of this operation is fully based on the speed of the reads/writes operations.

I guess we could speed up this query by creating hardlinks without the actual copying.

title: Add more functions for map data type

labels.name: pr-feature
labels.description: Pull request with new product feature

labels.name: doc-alert
labels.description: PR where any documentation work is needed or proceeded

body:
Changelog category (leave one):
- New Feature


Changelog entry (a user-readable short description of the changes that goes to CHANGELOG.md):
related to issue: https://github.com/ClickHouse/ClickHouse/issues/30715.
Add three functions for map data type:
1. mapReplace(map1, map2) - replaces values for keys in map1 with the values of the corresponding keys in map2; adds keys from map2 that don't exist in map1.
2. mapFilter 
3. mapMap 
mapFilter and mapMap are higher order functions , accept two arguments, first argument is  a lambda function with k, v pair , the second argument is a map type column.

Detailed description / Documentation draft:
Example:
```
select * from table_map:
┌───id─┬─col────────────────────────────────┐
│  100 │ {'key3':100,'key2':101,'key4':102} │
│  101 │ {'key3':101,'key2':102,'key4':103} │
│  102 │ {'key3':102,'key2':103,'key4':104} │
│  103 │ {'key3':103,'key2':104,'key4':105} │
│ 1111 │ {'key1':1111,'key2':2222}          │
│ 1112 │ {'key1':1112,'key2':2224}          │
│ 1113 │ {'key1':1113,'key2':2226}          │
└──────┴────────────────────────────────────┘

SELECT col, mapFilter((k, v) -> ((v % 10) > 1), col) FROM table_map ORDER BY id ASC;
┌─mapFilter(lambda(tuple(k, v), greater(modulo(v, 10), 1)), col)─┐
│ {'key4':102}                                                   │
│ {'key2':102,'key4':103}                                        │
│ {'key3':102,'key2':103,'key4':104}                             │
│ {'key3':103,'key2':104,'key4':105}                             │
│ {'key2':2222}                                                  │
│ {'key1':1112,'key2':2224}                                      │
│ {'key1':1113,'key2':2226}                                      │
└────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘


SELECT mapMap((k,v)->(k,v+1), col)  FROM table_map ORDER BY id;
┌─mapMap(lambda(tuple(k, v), tuple(k, plus(v, 1))), col)─┐
│ {'key3':101,'key2':102,'key4':103}                     │
│ {'key3':102,'key2':103,'key4':104}                     │
│ {'key3':103,'key2':104,'key4':105}                     │
│ {'key3':104,'key2':105,'key4':106}                     │
│ {'key1':1112,'key2':2223}                              │
│ {'key1':1113,'key2':2225}                              │
│ {'key1':1114,'key2':2227}                              │
└────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘
```

title: Wrong results are returned after TTL merge When there is skip index on the column with ttl.

labels.name: potential bug
labels.description: To be reviewed by developers and confirmed/rejected.

body:
**Describe what's wrong**
For a table with ttl, skip index and default value 'b' on a column named s, when I insert some rows, all the values in column s in a data part expire,  then ttl merge deletes this column from the data part in filesystem. Then a select on the table with an equal condition on the column s, "s='b'", where the value 'b' is the default value for column s, the skip index causes wrong result.

Since it is working as designed for column TTL, " When the values in the column expire, ClickHouse replaces them with the default values for the column data type. If all the column values in the data part expire, ClickHouse deletes this column from the data part in a filesystem.". For the problem part, there is no data column, should we return result for the query with condition on default value or not?

**Does it reproduce on recent release?**

CH 21.12.3.32 (official build).

**How to reproduce**

create table ttl (i Int, a Int, s String default 'b' ttl a % 2 = 0 ? today() - 10 : toDate('2100-01-01'),
    index ind_s (s) type set(1) granularity 1) engine = MergeTree order by i settings min_bytes_for_wide_part=0;

insert into ttl values(5,4,'a'),(6,6,'a');
insert into ttl values(1,1,'a'),(2,2,'a');

-- make sure the table is using wide part
select name, part_type from system.parts where table='ttl';

┌─name──────┬─part_type─┐
│ all_1_1_0 │ Wide      │
│ all_1_1_1 │ Wide      │ <<< TTL merge happens on the first part
│ all_2_2_0 │ Wide      │
└───────────┴───────────┘

-- List all the data in ttl
select * from ttl;

┌─i─┬─a─┬─s─┐
│ 1 │ 1 │ a │
│ 2 │ 2 │ a │
└───┴───┴───┘
┌─i─┬─a─┬─s─┐
│ 5 │ 4 │ b │
│ 6 │ 6 │ b │
└───┴───┴───┘

4 rows in set. Elapsed: 0.001 sec.

**-- For the select on s, it should return 2 rows.**
select * from ttl where s='b';

SELECT *
FROM ttl
WHERE s = 'b'

Query id: 0f8ab129-5aad-4f67-a6ee-6fdacdeff515

Ok.

**0 rows in set**. Elapsed: 0.001 sec.

**Expected behavior**
-- Should return 2 rows.
┌─i─┬─a─┬─s─┐
│ 5 │ 4 │ b │
│ 6 │ 6 │ b │
└───┴───┴───┘

**Additional context**
In the data directory, the part after ttl merge doesn't have files for column s, but only the skp index files. all the granuales are dropped by the skip index.

title: [Umbrella] Boosting the Projection feature
body:
The Projection feature has been available for eight months now, and it's been used by several brave users under the experimental flag. I think it's time to make some dedicated effort to get it into a production-ready state.

The feature is tangled with many other core parts of ClickHouse, which results in several corner cases. The following list of tasks is ordered by priority:

## Make tests green (Required)

- [ ] https://github.com/ClickHouse/ClickHouse/pull/30144 
- [ ] https://github.com/ClickHouse/ClickHouse/issues/30146
- [ ] https://github.com/ClickHouse/ClickHouse/issues/33010
- [ ] https://github.com/ClickHouse/ClickHouse/issues/31401

## More features (Optional)

- [ ] Treat projection as real tables which can specify column codecs, indices, etc https://github.com/ClickHouse/ClickHouse/issues/28932
- [ ] Allow to ALTER projection columns (add, drop). Only columns added by the ADD COLUMN command in the same ALTER query are allowed in newly added projection columns, without default column value. This is similar to ALTER ORDER BY.
- [ ] Make projection smarter. https://github.com/ClickHouse/ClickHouse/issues/24779, https://github.com/ClickHouse/ClickHouse/issues/24810, https://github.com/ClickHouse/ClickHouse/issues/26369, https://github.com/ClickHouse/ClickHouse/issues/32488, https://github.com/ClickHouse/ClickHouse/issues/32753
- [ ] Support WHERE clause for projection. https://github.com/ClickHouse/ClickHouse/issues/33587
- [ ] TTL which leaves only projections or only the original data. https://github.com/ClickHouse/ClickHouse/issues/26578, https://github.com/ClickHouse/ClickHouse/issues/9436
- [ ] Indices via projection. https://github.com/ClickHouse/ClickHouse/issues/30530, https://github.com/ClickHouse/ClickHouse/issues/14694
- [ ] More use cases of projections for different types MergeTree engines https://github.com/ClickHouse/ClickHouse/issues/24778, https://github.com/ClickHouse/ClickHouse/issues/28311
- [ ] More types of projection engines https://github.com/ClickHouse/ClickHouse/issues/33615
- [ ] Allow putting projection parts into different storage media. This can be achieved after our cache mechanism. https://github.com/ClickHouse/ClickHouse/issues/28961
- [ ] ProjectionMergeTree https://github.com/ClickHouse/ClickHouse/issues/4419

The task list is not meant to be complete. Please feel free to add anything useful.

title: Implement arithmetic operations between big integers and floating point.

labels.name: st-discussion
labels.description: The story requires discussion /research / expert help / design & decomposition before will be taken

body:
**Use case**

```
SELECT 10000000000000000000::UInt128 * 1.0
```

**Describe the solution you'd like**

Convert to `Float64`, then perform the operation.

**Additional context**

It can lead to surprises, example:

```
SELECT 10000000000000000000::UInt128 + 1.0
```

title: Better EXPLAIN ESTIMATE

labels.name: comp-optimizers
labels.description: Query optimizations

body:
Now Clickhouse shows only parts, rows, marks.
But Clickhouse knows which parts & columns need to read, so it's possible to predict number of compressed and uncompressed bytes. 
Because in some cases estimate in rows can be the same but because of columns query can be light or heavy.

```sql
CREATE TABLE perf( dt DateTime, metric_id Int64, S String ) ENGINE = MergeTree 
PARTITION BY toYYYYMMDD(dt) ORDER BY ( metric_id, dt);


INSERT INTO perf SELECT
    toDateTime('2021-12-21 00:00:00') + (number / 20),
    number % 1111,
    toString(arrayMap(i -> cityHash64(i * number), range(20)))
FROM numbers(1000000);

explain estimate SELECT dt FROM perf 
┌─database─┬─table─┬─parts─┬────rows─┬─marks─┐
│ default  │ perf  │     1 │ 1000000 │   123 │
└──────────┴───────┴───────┴─────────┴───────┘

SELECT dt FROM perf format Null
0 rows in set. Elapsed: 0.008 sec. Processed 1.00 million rows, 4.00 MB

explain estimate SELECT dt,S FROM perf 
┌─database─┬─table─┬─parts─┬────rows─┬─marks─┐
│ default  │ perf  │     1 │ 1000000 │   123 │
└──────────┴───────┴───────┴─────────┴───────┘

SELECT dt, S FROM perf format Null
0 rows in set. Elapsed: 0.145 sec. Processed 1.00 million rows, 421.55 MB 
```

`4.00 MB` VS `421.55 MB`

title: ROLLUP on constant column doesn't produce subtotal row
body:
Tested on 21.12.3.32 .

Query:
```sql
select key, sum(value) as result from (select 1 as key, 1 as value) group by key with rollup;
key	result
1	1
0	1


select 1 as key, sum(value) as result from (select 1 as value) group by key with rollup;
key	result
1	1
```
I would have expected both queries to produce the same result (the former, with the subtotal).

For comparison, MySQL produces the same result for both:
```sql
select mykey, sum(value) as result from (select 1 as mykey, 1 as value) as subquery group by mykey with rollup;
|  mykey | result |
|--------|--------|
|      1 |      1 |
| (null) |      1 |
        

select 1 as mykey, sum(value) as result from (select 1 as value) as subquery group by mykey with rollup;
|  mykey | result |
|--------|--------|
|      1 |      1 |
| (null) |      1 |
```
And postgres:

```sql
select mykey, sum(value) as result from (select 1 as mykey, 1 as value) as subquery group by rollup(mykey);
|  mykey | result |
|--------|--------|
|      1 |      1 |
| (null) |      1 |

select 1 as mykey, sum(value) as result from (select 1 as value) as subquery group by rollup(mykey);
|  mykey | result |
|--------|--------|
|      1 |      1 |
| (null) |      1 |
```

title: Provide a new setting to control `X-ClickHouse-Summary` header
body:
**Use case**

We have multiple large clusters, and we have some reverse-proxy servers to proxy all client requests to ClickHouse clusters via HTTP. We also collect some metrics from these proxy servers. among those metrics, the query level metrics, which is stored in the `X-ClickHouse-Summary` header, are also collected.

To ask ClickHouse nodes put correct values in `X-ClickHouse-Summary`, we need to put `send_progress_in_http_headers=1` on the request url. But this switch also asks ClickHouse to send `X-ClickHouse-Progress` header to the client, which is obviously no use for the proxy servers and the client.  

The progress header is sent to client at a default 100ms interval. If there's time-consuming query, there will be lots of such header in the HTTP response, which causes an extra-large HTTP header. Many proxy servers have size limitation on the HTTP header, for example 8KiB by default on some netty servers, such size limitation will lead to a failure of proxying.

Currently there's no way to disable this progress header while enabling the summary header at the same time unless by setting `http_headers_progress_interval_ms` to a very large value.  

In this case, we only want ClickHouse nodes return `X-ClickHouse-Summary` header, so any changes on the setting of the progress seems very strange.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

This proposal here is to define an independent setting, for example `send_summary_in_http_headers`, which has nothing to do with `send_progress_in_http_headers`, although internally they may share same progress callback.

By defult, this new setting is disabled to make it compatible with current behaviour.


If the proposal is OK, I will open a PR.

title: PROJECTION lalala (SELECT DISTINCT key_a ORDER BY key_a)
body:
**Use case**

Nasty bi tools, which tries to run 

```sql
SELECT DISTINCT key FROM table ORDER BY key ASC NULLS FIRST ...
```
query against multi billion row table in order to populate selector (I'm looking at you DataLens) 
 
**Describe the solution you'd like**

```sql
CREATE TABLE table(
key UInt32,
value UInt32,
ts DateTime,
PROJECTION selector_key (
SELECT DISTINCT key ORDER BY key))
ENGINE=MergeTree PARTITION BY toYYYYMM(ts) ORDER BY (key)
```

title: Change `group by` keys order according to the `order by` keys order when aggregating in order
body:
**Describe the situation**
These two queries have different running times.

```
nickitat-nix :) show create table test

┌─statement──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ CREATE TABLE default.test
(
    `a` UInt64,
    `b` UInt64
)
ENGINE = MergeTree
ORDER BY (a, b)
SETTINGS index_granularity = 8192 │
└────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘
```

```
nickitat-nix :) select count(*) from test group by a, b order by a, b format Null settings optimize_aggregation_in_order = 1

0 rows in set. Elapsed: 1.264 sec. Processed 10.00 million rows, 160.00 MB (7.91 million rows/s., 126.59 MB/s.)
```

```
nickitat-nix :) select count(*) from test group by b, a order by a, b format Null settings optimize_aggregation_in_order = 1

0 rows in set. Elapsed: 3.493 sec. Processed 10.00 million rows, 160.00 MB (2.86 million rows/s., 45.81 MB/s.)
```

**Expected performance**
The same in both cases.

**Additional context**
For example PG executes both in the same time.

```
postgres=# \d+ test
                                   Table "public.test"
 Column |  Type  | Collation | Nullable | Default | Storage | Stats target | Description 
--------+--------+-----------+----------+---------+---------+--------------+-------------
 a      | bigint |           |          |         | plain   |              | 
 b      | bigint |           |          |         | plain   |              | 
Indexes:
    "xxxxxx" btree (a, b)

postgres=# explain select a, b, count(*) from test group by a, b order by a, b;
                                        QUERY PLAN                                        
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 GroupAggregate  (cost=0.42..117584.43 rows=1000000 width=24)
   Group Key: a, b
   ->  Index Only Scan using xxxxxx on test  (cost=0.42..100084.43 rows=1000000 width=16)

postgres=# explain select a, b, count(*) from test group by b, a order by a, b;
                                        QUERY PLAN                                        
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 GroupAggregate  (cost=0.42..117584.43 rows=1000000 width=24)
   Group Key: a, b
   ->  Index Only Scan using xxxxxx on test  (cost=0.42..100084.43 rows=1000000 width=16)
```

title: STORJ instead of S3?
body:
**Use case** Shard out to STORJ instead of S3

**Describe the solution you'd like**: STORJ is **about 6 times cheaper** than S3 and is:
- cheaper - Oh! I said that already!
- more secure - you do not have to trust STORJ or node operators - nobody knows what they store and they can't use the data. On the other hand, you have to trust Amazon with your ClickHouse data, which is... Ha-ha! No.
- has no downtime as it is decentralized cloud storage: data is torn to pieces, encrypted and spread across thousands of nodes all over the world 
...

title: clickhouse-local - support shebang

labels.name: easy task
labels.description: Good for first contributors

body:
**Use case**

Since clickhouse-local act like a repl now, that would be logical to allow it to execute sql statements with shebang
That would be useful for cronjob scripts and CH based tool building (e.g. format convertor), etc
```bash
#!/usr/bin/env -S clichouse-local  --input-format Parquet
select * from table FORMAT Pretty
```

title: trait for Skip index filtering before ORDER BY index

labels.name: st-need-info
labels.description: We need extra data to continue

labels.name: st-discussion
labels.description: The story requires discussion /research / expert help / design & decomposition before will be taken

body:
**Use case**

In specific use cases, we may want to create skip index, which will have high granularity and are going to be used as part skipping index.
But now, it will be applied after ORDER BY index, which can lead to major slowdown in case of big table with a lot of rows.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

Special trait, which will specify order in which ClickHouse need to use skip index (and ORDER BY index)

```
CREATE TABLE table (
key UInt32,
ts DateTime,
ts2 DateTime,
value String,
INDEX ts2_idx ts2 TYPE minmax GRANULARITY 1000 BEFORE ORDER BY,
INDEX key_idx key TYPE minmax GRANULARITY 50 BEFORE value_idx,
INDEX value_idx value TYPE minmax GRANULARITY 10)
ENGINE=MergeTree PARTITION BY toYYYYMM(ts) ORDER BY key;
```

title: JOIN algorithm to properly use key-value tables.
body:
**Use case**

There are table engines that support key-value requests efficiently. Mainly, `EmbeddedRocksDB` and more to come.
But if you JOIN with that table, it is using one large request to form a hash table in memory and process lookups from the hash table.

While hash table in memory can serve 250 000 000 totally random requests per second (and more than a billion if it fits in cache) and RocksDB backed by array of NVMe SSDs with non-skewed distribution of requests can serve not more than single millions requests per second, it can be still good when data does not fit in memory.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

Requires (2) from here: #33581

Add `join_algorithm = 'direct'` that will force direct requests when it is possible.

**Additional context**

It will not work out of the box for RIGHT and FULL JOIN, we can use other join algorithms for that cases.

title: Key-value Data Marts

labels.name: st-community-taken
labels.description: External developer is working on that

body:
**Use case**

ClickHouse should be able to serve large amount of short queries on prepared datasets.

For example, you can prepare a dataset for user personalization or antifraud and serve it directly by clickhouse-server in realtime in ad-network, RTB, for DDoS prevention, e-commerce apps, games, etc...

**Describe the solution you'd like**

1. clickhouse-server should have TCPHandler that will implement Redis or Memcached protocol.
2. Add `get` method to `IStorage` interface and `supportsGetRequests`. The method takes array of Fields and returns array of Fields.
3. Implement this method for `StorageDictionary`, `EmbeddedRocksDB`, `Join`, `Set` and (when it will be ready), `AggregatingMemory`. Then implement it for `Distributed` tables.

title: Server falls when execute EXPLAIN
body:
Clickhouse run in Docker with 2 CPU and 3GB RAM. All settings are default.

When I execute EXPLAIN my query, server falls.

Reproduce:

1. Create any table:

```sql
CREATE TABLE stock (
    id UInt64,
    dd DateTime,
    val1 Int64,
    val2 Int64,
    val3 Int64,
    val4 Int64,
    val5 Int64,
    type Int8,
    state Int8,
    reference UInt64
) ENGINE = MergeTree()
ORDER BY (dd, id)
PARTITION BY toYYYYMM(dd);
```

2. Run first EXPLAIN, that response error `Code: 168. DB::Exception: AST is too big. Maximum: 500000: (after expansion of aliases). (TOO_BIG_AST) (version 21.12.2.17 (official build))`:

```sql
explain
with
    '2020-01-01 00:00:00' as beginPeriod,
    '2021-12-31 23:59:59' as endPeriod,
    all_stock as (select * from default.stock where dd between beginPeriod and endPeriod),
    cancels as (select reference as transactionId from all_stock where type = 9),
    full_returned as (
        select id
        from (
            select t.id,
                sum(t.val1 + trc.val1) as val1,
                sum(t.val2 + trc.val2) as val2,
                sum(t.val3 + trc.val3) as val3,
                sum(t.val4 + trc.val4) as val4
            from all_stock as t
            left join (
                select *
                from all_stock
                where type = 7 and id not in (cancels)
            ) as trc on (t.id = trc.reference)
            where trc.reference > 0
            group by id
            ) as ts
        where ts.val1 = 0 and ts.val2 = 0 and ts.val3 = 0 and ts.val4 = 0
    ),
    normal_stock as (
        select *
        from all_stock
        where id not in (cancels) and id not in (full_returned)
    ),
    without_returns as (select * from all_stock where id not in (cancels)),
    (select count() from normal_stock where val5 > 0 and type < 7) as field_3,
    (select sum(val1) from normal_stock where val5 = 0 and type < 7) as field_4,
    (select sum(val2) from normal_stock where val5 = 0 and type < 7) as field_5,
    (select count() from normal_stock where val5 > 0 and type < 7 and state = 3) as field_6,
    (select sum(val1) from normal_stock where val5 = 0 and type < 7 and state = 3) as field_7,
    (select sum(abs(val3)) from normal_stock where type = 11) as field_8,
    (select sum(val4) from (
        select argMax(val4, dd) val4 from normal_stock where type < 7 group by state
    )) as field_9,
    
    /* After expressions below we get error. If there is no line below, then there is enough memory to execute EXPLAIN. */

    (select round(avg(val4)/count(), 0) from (
        select argMax(val4, dd) as val4 from normal_stock where state > 0 group by state
    )) as field_10,
    (select sum(val1)/count() from without_returns where val5 > 0 and type < 7) as field_11,
    (select sum(val1)/count() from without_returns where val5 > 0 and type < 7 and state = 3) as field_12,
    (select sum(val1 - val2)/count() from without_returns where val5 > 0 and type < 7) as field_13,
    (select sum(val2) from all_stock where id not in (cancels) and type < 7) as field_14,
    (select sum(val2)/count() from all_stock where id not in (cancels) and type < 7 and val2 > 0) as field_15,
    (select sum(val3) from all_stock where type in (1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 9)) as field_16,

    (select sum(val2) from all_stock where type = 8 and val3 > 0) as field_28
select
    beginPeriod,    /*  1 */
    endPeriod,      /*  2 */
    field_3,        /*  3 */
    field_4,        /*  4 */
    field_5,        /*  5 */
    field_6,        /*  6 */
    field_7,        /*  7 */
    field_8,        /*  8 */
    field_9,        /*  9 */

    field_10,       /* 10 */
    field_11,       /* 11 */
    field_12,       /* 12 */
    field_13,       /* 13 */
    field_14,       /* 14 */
    field_15,       /* 15 */
    field_16,       /* 16 */

    field_28        /* 28 */;
```

3. Let's add one more expression, and then the query will be like this:

```sql
explain
with
    '2020-01-01 00:00:00' as beginPeriod,
    '2021-12-31 23:59:59' as endPeriod,
    all_stock as (select * from default.stock where dd between beginPeriod and endPeriod),
    cancels as (select reference as transactionId from all_stock where type = 9),
    full_returned as (
        select id
        from (
            select t.id,
                sum(t.val1 + trc.val1) as val1,
                sum(t.val2 + trc.val2) as val2,
                sum(t.val3 + trc.val3) as val3,
                sum(t.val4 + trc.val4) as val4
            from all_stock as t
            left join (
                select *
                from all_stock
                where type = 7 and id not in (cancels)
            ) as trc on (t.id = trc.reference)
            where trc.reference > 0
            group by id
            ) as ts
        where ts.val1 = 0 and ts.val2 = 0 and ts.val3 = 0 and ts.val4 = 0
    ),
    normal_stock as (
        select *
        from all_stock
        where id not in (cancels) and id not in (full_returned)
    ),
    without_returns as (select * from all_stock where id not in (cancels)),
    (select count() from normal_stock where val5 > 0 and type < 7) as field_3,
    (select sum(val1) from normal_stock where val5 = 0 and type < 7) as field_4,
    (select sum(val2) from normal_stock where val5 = 0 and type < 7) as field_5,
    (select count() from normal_stock where val5 > 0 and type < 7 and state = 3) as field_6,
    (select sum(val1) from normal_stock where val5 = 0 and type < 7 and state = 3) as field_7,
    (select sum(abs(val3)) from normal_stock where type = 11) as field_8,
    (select sum(val4) from (
        select argMax(val4, dd) val4 from normal_stock where type < 7 group by state
    )) as field_9,

    (select round(avg(val4)/count(), 0) from (
        select argMax(val4, dd) as val4 from normal_stock where state > 0 group by state
    )) as field_10,
    (select sum(val1)/count() from without_returns where val5 > 0 and type < 7) as field_11,
    (select sum(val1)/count() from without_returns where val5 > 0 and type < 7 and state = 3) as field_12,
    (select sum(val1 - val2)/count() from without_returns where val5 > 0 and type < 7) as field_13,
    (select sum(val2) from all_stock where id not in (cancels) and type < 7) as field_14,
    (select sum(val2)/count() from all_stock where id not in (cancels) and type < 7 and val2 > 0) as field_15,
    (select sum(val3) from all_stock where type in (1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 9)) as field_16,

    (select field_16/count() from all_stock where type in (1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 9) and val3 > 0) as field_17,

    (select sum(val2) from all_stock where type = 8 and val3 > 0) as field_28
select
    beginPeriod,    /*  1 */
    endPeriod,      /*  2 */
    field_3,        /*  3 */
    field_4,        /*  4 */
    field_5,        /*  5 */
    field_6,        /*  6 */
    field_7,        /*  7 */
    field_8,        /*  8 */
    field_9,        /*  9 */

    field_10,       /* 10 */
    field_11,       /* 11 */
    field_12,       /* 12 */
    field_13,       /* 13 */
    field_14,       /* 14 */
    field_15,       /* 15 */
    field_16,       /* 16 */

    field_17,       /* 17 */

    field_28        /* 28 */;
```

Oops... Server falls. Because there was not enough memory.

Any user can crash the server - classic DoS.

Why is EXPLAIN so memory hungry? As example, sometimes it happens.

Query:
```sql
EXPLAIN
WITH
    '2020-01-01 00:00:00' AS beginPeriod,
    '2021-12-31 23:59:59' AS endPeriod,
    all_transactions AS
    (
        SELECT *
        FROM cns.transactions
        WHERE (dateBuy >= beginPeriod) AND (dateBuy <= endPeriod)
    ),
    cancels AS
    (
        SELECT reference AS transactionId
        FROM all_transactions
        WHERE type = 9
    ),
    full_returned AS
    (
        SELECT transactionId
        FROM
        (
            SELECT
                t.transactionId,
                sum(t.amount + trc.amount) AS amount,
                sum(t.amountDiscount + trc.amountDiscount) AS amountDiscount,
                sum(t.amountBonus + trc.amountBonus) AS amountBonus,
                sum(t.amountCharge + trc.amountCharge) AS amountCharge
            FROM all_transactions AS t
            LEFT JOIN
            (
                SELECT *
                FROM all_transactions
                WHERE (type = 7) AND (transactionId NOT IN (cancels))
            ) AS trc ON t.transactionId = trc.reference
            WHERE trc.reference > 0
            GROUP BY transactionId
        ) AS ts
        WHERE (ts.amount = 0) AND (ts.amountDiscount = 0) AND (ts.amountBonus = 0) AND (ts.amountCharge = 0)
    ),
    normal_transactions AS
    (
        SELECT *
        FROM all_transactions
        WHERE (transactionId NOT IN (cancels)) AND (transactionId NOT IN (full_returned))
    ),
    without_returns AS
    (
        SELECT *
        FROM all_transactions
        WHERE transactionId NOT IN (cancels)
    ),
    (
        SELECT count()
        FROM normal_transactions
        WHERE (cardId > 0) AND (type < 7)
    ) AS cnt_with_cards
SELECT cnt_with_cards
```

Error:
```
Received exception from server (version 21.12.2):
Code: 241. DB::Exception: Received from x.x.x.x:9000. DB::Exception: Memory limit (total) exceeded: would use 3.94 GiB (attempt to allocate chunk of 0 bytes), maximum: 2.79 GiB: While executing AggregatingTransform: While processing (WITH '2020-01-01 00:00:00' AS beginPeriod, '2021-12-31 23:59:59' AS endPeriod SELECT count() FROM normal_transactions WHERE (cardId > 0) AND (type < 7)) AS cnt_with_cards. (MEMORY_LIMIT_EXCEEDED)
```

Hm... `While executing AggregatingTransform` in EXPLAIN? Why?

P.S. In all cases the tables are empty.

body:
